  1. A binomial is an algebraic expression of two terms which are connected by the operations ' + ' or ' - '. e.g. ( x + 2 ) ( x + 2 ) (x+2)(x+2)(x+2)

The binomial theorem for natural numbers states that -

Example:

The total number of terms in the expansion of ( x + y + z ) 10 = ( x + y + z ) 10 = (x+y+z)^(10)=(x+y+z)^{10}=(x+y+z)10=
a) 55
b) 66
c) 60
d) 75

Solution:-

Total number of terms = ( n + 1 ) ( n + 2 ) 2 = ( 10 + 1 ) ( 10 + 2 ) 2 = 11 × 6 = 66  Total number of terms  = ( n + 1 ) ( n + 2 ) 2 = ( 10 + 1 ) ( 10 + 2 ) 2 = 11 × 6 = 66 {:[" Total number of terms "=((n+1)(n+2))/(2)],[=((10+1)(10+2))/(2)],[=11 xx6],[=66]:}\begin{aligned} & \text { Total number of terms }=\frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2} \\ & =\frac{(10+1)(10+2)}{2} \\ & =11 \times 6 \\ & =66 \end{aligned} Total number of terms =(n+1)(n+2)2=(10+1)(10+2)2=11×6=66
Alternate Method,
n = 10 m = 3 total number of terms = C ( n + m − 1 , n ) = C ( 10 + 3 − 1 , 10 ) = C ( 12 , 10 ) = C ( 12 , 2 ) = ( 12 × 11 ) / 1.2 = 66 n = 10 m = 3  total number of terms  = C ( n + m − 1 , n ) = C ( 10 + 3 − 1 , 10 ) = C ( 12 , 10 ) = C ( 12 , 2 ) = ( 12 × 11 ) / 1.2 = 66 {:[n=10],[m=3],[" total number of terms "=C(n+m-1","n)],[=C(10+3-1","10)],[=C(12","10)],[=C(12","2)=(12 xx11)//1.2=66]:}\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{n}=10 \\ & \mathrm{~m}=3 \\ & \text { total number of terms }=C(n+m-1, n) \\ & =C(10+3-1,10) \\ & =C(12,10) \\ & =C(12,2)=(12 \times 11) / 1.2=66 \end{aligned}n=10 m=3 total number of terms =C(n+m−1,n)=C(10+3−1,10)=C(12,10)=C(12,2)=(12×11)/1.2=66
